titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Press photographs of Hartford, Connecticut Black Caucus protests and meetings, 1967 September-October RL.11878
titlestmt.author: Paula Jeannet

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-02-11 17:01:35 -0500.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Press photographs of Hartford, Connecticut Black Caucus protests and meetings

origination.label: source
origination.corpname: John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture

physdesc.dimensions: Print sizes: 8 1/2 x 6 1/2 inches; image sizes vary.

did.abstract: The Hartford Times was a daily newspaper for Hartford, Connecticut. Collection consists of 50 black-and-white press photographs taken by Hartford Times staff of Black Caucus protests and marches in Fall 1967, and associated community meetings. Subjects include Black Caucus members, African American residents, student protesters, state and city officials, police, religious leaders, and the press. Protest images show Black Caucus members marching through Hartford and gathering in the State Capitol Building and in Bushnell Park. Individuals highlighted in the images are: John Barber; Boce W. Barlow, Jr.; Rev. Collin Bennett; Lewis Fox; George B. Kinsella; Rev. Robert A. Moody; Robert Morris; and Wilber Smith. Acquired as part of the John Hope Center for African and African American History and Culture, and the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Photographs are arranged in chronological order.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Hartford Times was the daily afternoon newspaper for Hartford, Connecticut. Its photographers assigned to cover the Black Caucus marches were Einar G. Chindmark, Grover W. Grogan, Ellery G. Kington, and S. Robert Pugliese.

The Black Caucus of Hartford was formed sometime in the first half of 1967 by residents of the North End, a segregated neighborhood where most of the African Americans in Hartford lived, and where they faced systemic discriminatory practices, including substandard housing and education, and police harassment. By 1970 the group seems to have disbanded, but individuals continued their civil rights work with other community groups and organizations.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. Images may only be used for educational, non-commercial purposes; any other use requires the photographer's permission. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Press photographs of Hartford, Connecticut Black Caucus protests and meetings were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 2020.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred Citation: [Identification of item], Press photographs of Hartford, Connecticut Black Caucus protests and meetings, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed and described by Paula Jeannet, February 2021.
Accession(s) represented in this collection guide: 2020-0056.

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of 50 black-and-white press photographs taken by Hartford Times reporters of Black Caucus protests in Hartford, Connecticut in September and October, 1967, and associated community meetings. Individuals featured in the images include Black Caucus members, African American citizens of the North End, other Black and White activists, student protesters, state and city officials, police, religious leaders, and the press.

About a quarter of the prints are of protest images, and show Black Caucus leaders and members marching peacefully through Hartford and gathering in the State Capitol Building and in Bushnell Park with college student supporters. Images of meetings show speakers as well as the audiences.

Among the individuals highlighted in the images are: John Barber, Black Caucus spokesperson; Boce Barlow, Jr., first Black State Judge and State Senator; Collin Bennett, Black City Council member; Lewis Fox, local attorney and Board of Education member; George B. Kinsella, Hartford's mayor; Rev. Robert A. Moody, a Black Baptist minister and community activist; Robert Morris, Black Caucus spokesperson; and Wilber G. Smith, Black attorney, civil rights activist and, later, State Senator. Many other state and city officials are also present in the meeting images.

p.extref: James Karales Photographs, 1953-2006 (photographs taken at civil rights marches)
Spider Martin Photographs, 1965, 1968 (photographs taken at civil rights marches)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: These fifty press photographs documenting the Fall 1967 Hartford, Connecticut Black Caucus protests and meetings are arranged in chronological order. Almost all titles and dates originating from notes or captions on the backs of the prints.

did.unittitle: FOR THE RECORD - Officer Stephen Hankard tape records John Barber's conversation with Capt. Benjamin Goldstein
did.physdesc: Gelatin silver print. Dimensions: 6 1/2 x 8 1/2 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edition run notes and newsprint caption glued on verso. Title taken from caption. Date in pencil on verso.

did.physdesc: Gelatin silver print. Dimensions: 8 1/2 x 6 1/2 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edition run notes glued on verso. Slug for article is "Walk" - image is of group of Black Caucus members walking down the sidewalk at night. Title taken from caption. Date in pencil on verso.

did.unittitle: ON THE LINE - Black Caucus spokesman makes a point during meeting with Mayor George Kinsella in Police Department Lobby
did.physdesc: Gelatin silver print. Dimensions: 8 1/2 x 6 1/2 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Caption continues, "Group, which included Negroes and whites, surrounds pair along with press and police. Session over, group heads up up Morgan Street towards Main Street and home." Edition run notes and newsprint caption glued on verso. Title taken from caption. Date in pencil on verso.

did.unittitle: John J. Gale - AIM president - (American Independent Movement) - Hall High School teacher
did.physdesc: Gelatin silver print. Dimensions: 6 1/2 x 8 1/2 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Date and title from print verso. Black Caucus meeting. John J. Gale (1920-2001) was the Hartford chairman of AIM, a political organization that appears to be still active, currently based in San Diego.

did.physdesc: Gelatin silver print. Dimensions: 6 1/2 x 8 1/2 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Date and title from print verso. Black Caucus meeting. The Reverend Collin B. Bennett (1931-1998) was a native of Jamaica and came to Connecticut in 1951, where he became a realtor. He was elected to the city council in 1965. (Source: Hartford Public Library "Hartford Changemakers web page, accessed Jan. 28, 2021)

did.physdesc: Gelatin silver print. Dimensions: 6 1/2 x 8 1/2 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Date and title from print verso. Black Caucus meeting. Boce W. Barlow, Jr. (1915-2005) was Connecticut's first Black municipal court judge and first Black state senator. (Source: Hartford Public Library "Hartford Changemakers" web page, accessed Jan. 28, 2021)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Caption continues, "From left: James Brown, Francis Gamble, Robert Morris, and John Barber." Title taken from caption on print verso. Date in pencil on verso. Edition run notes and newsprint caption glued on verso. Editorial and crop marks on front of print in orange pencil. Slug for article noted as "John Barber."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Date and title from print verso. Thomas Bodine (1915-2005) served as a Commissioner of the Hartford Housing Authority for over 20 years. He was Chairman of the Community Renewal Team, from 1967-1970. (Source: Hartford Courant obituary web page, accessed Jan. 28, 2021)

did.physdesc: Gelatin silver print. Dimensions: 8 1/2 x 6 1/2 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Title taken from caption on print verso. Date in pencil on verso. Edition run notes and newsprint caption glued on verso. Later date stamp, October 4. Editorial and crop marks on front of print in orange pencil. Slug for article noted as "Crowd."

did.unittitle: SOGGY RALLY - John Barber of Hartford's Black Caucus, wearing striped cap, addresses group at Constitution Plaza.
did.physdesc: Gelatin silver print. Dimensions: 8 1/2 x 6 1/2 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Caption continues, "Rain held attendance down as Barber promised further demonstrations." Title taken from caption on print verso. Date is taken from earlier photograph from the same march. Edition run notes and newsprint caption glued on verso. Later date stamp, Sept. 30. Editorial marks on front of print in green. Slug for article noted as "Crowd." "Black Caucus" also pencilled on verso.

did.unittitle: BLACK CAUCUS marchers led by John Barber are flanked by line of policemen, right, Friday night
did.physdesc: Gelatin silver print. Dimensions: 8 1/2 x 6 1/2 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Newsprint caption glued on verso. Title taken from caption. Date is taken from earlier photograph from the same march. Later date stamp, Sept. 30. "Black Caucus - March to South End of Hartford" and "Main St and Pratt [?]" also pencilled on verso.

did.physdesc: Gelatin silver print. Dimensions: 8 1/2 x 6 1/2 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Large group of protesters, photographed from above, in the Hall of Flags, Hartford State Capitol Building. Date appears in pencil on print verso.

did.physdesc: Gelatin silver print. Dimensions: 8 1/2 x 6 1/2 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Group of protesters walk down the sidewalk next to a parking lot. Date appears in pencil on print verso. Later date stamp, Oct. 12.

did.unittitle: MARCHERS escorted by police file quietly through West Hartford during Black Caucus demonstration Friday night
did.physdesc: Gelatin silver print. Dimensions: 8 1/2 x 6 1/2 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Newsprint caption glued on verso. Title taken from caption; date from note on print verso. Later date stamp, Oct. 14. "Black Caucus" also pencilled on verso. Single editorial mark on front. The actual date for Friday night, mentioned in the caption, would have been Oct. 13; thus this may be a different protest than that at Bushnell Park, one night earlier on Oct. 12 according to dates on the prints.
